thread.title: Yankees downplay Jose Quintana in show of rotation faith
thread.title_full: Yankees downplay Jose Quintana in show of rotation faith | New York Post

author: George A. King III
title: Yankees downplay Jose Quintana in show of rotation faith
text:
TAMPA — With the baseball universe expecting the rebuilding White Sox to part with lefty starter Jose Quintana at some point and the Yankees having at least two question marks in their rotation, the clubs have been linked and the presence of White Sox scouts at Yankees games hasn’t gone unnoticed.
The 28-year-old Quintana, who has two years and $16.35 million left on a team-friendly deal that has $10.5 million club options for 2019 and 2020, could help the Yankees, Pirates, Astros, Rangers and Mariners — all teams with postseason aspirations.
Though Quintana, a former Yankees minor leaguer who has a 46-46 career record and has pitched 200 or more innings the past four seasons, would jump into the No. 2 spot behind ace Masahiro Tanaka, GM Brian Cashman said the rotation likely will be filled out from within.
“We’re not expecting to go elsewhere,’’ Cashman said via phone Monday from West Palm Beach, where the Yankees played the Nationals. “I’m expecting we will go with what we got.’’
Entering spring training, Luis Severino and Bryan Mitchell were believed to be the favorites for the final two spots behind CC Sabathia and Michael Pineda. As late as this past Saturday, those two names rolled off the lips of scouts from other teams who had seen the right-handers as well as Adam Warren, Luis Cessa and Chad Green.
SEE ALSO 
Yankees prospect comes from out of nowhere into Opening Day picture 0:0 LAKELAND, Fla. — Joe Girardi said he was “really curious”... In some eyes, lefty Jordan Montgomery has pushed himself into the conversation, but if the rookie makes the club, it’s more likely to be in long relief. And some believe the 24-year-old would be better served opening the season in Triple-A Scranton/Wilkes-Barre’s rotation. He went 5-1 with a 0.97 ERA in six starts at Triple-A last season.
When Severino got spanked for three runs and six hits in 3 1/3 innings by the Astros on Sunday in West Palm Beach, it raised the question: Do Yankees have enough starting pitching to chase a postseason bid with what they have?
Cashman, who isn’t likely to trade the prospects the organization has developed or the ones he got for Andrew Miller and Aroldis Chapman last July, says the final two starters will be decided shortly.
“We have to lock in sooner than later,’’ Cashman said. “And one of those guys isn’t going to pitch until the 16th [of April] with days off. We have to make some decisions soon and get people in the right spots, whether it’s the bullpen or Scranton.’’
Joe Girardi takes the ball from Luis Severino during a March 3 exhibition game. Charles Wenzelberg Those decisions could come within a few days.
“We have had one official roster meeting and the next roster meeting is coming up this week,’’ Cashman said.
A scout said, “For any team that has a chance to win, starting pitching is essential. The Yankees have questions in the back of the rotation, and don’t forget Sabathia and Pineda. If they somehow would get Quintana, it would make everybody there feel better.’’
Thirteen days before Opening Day against the Rays in St. Petersburg, it sounds as if the Yankees are willing to go with what is already wearing pinstripes.
